elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have been attracting a great deal of attention as potential solid electrolytes (SEs). However, the interfacial compatibility of MOF-based SEs caused by the physical contact among MOF particles, the polymer binder, and electrodes is not yet fully determined. Herein, a bioinspired design strategy aiming to build ion transport pathways at interfaces was introduced. The MOF-to-MOF transport paths were built via in situ ring opening of epoxide, akin to the protein molecules that transport the ion across the cell walls. After optimization, the obtained SE is endowed with a high ion conductivity of 1.70 × 10–3 S cm–1 at 30 °C, a wide electrochemical window of 4.6 V, a high Li+ transference number of 0.8, and a decreased interface resistance. Consequently, the fabricated quasi-solid metal batteries exhibit higher and more stable cycling performance compared to the performance of those without interface optimization. This strategy for optimizing the interfacial compatibility of MOFs thus exploits a new avenue for developing high-performance SEs for various metal batteries.

elements.content: The development of solid electrolytes (SEs) with excellent ion conductivity (>10–4 S cm–1), a high ion transport number, good stability, and low interface impedance is imperative for high-performance solid-state batteries (SSBs). Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have been intensively investigated as potential SEs due to their diversified structures and chemical tunability. Originally, MOFs were applied as the host for ion conductive materials such as ionic liquids (ILs) and polymers. As a result, the aggregation of ILs and/or polymers can be hindered, rendering an improved ion conductivity, for instance, by 2 orders of magnitude to the range of 10–6 to 10–4 S cm–1. However, this host–guest system suffers from relatively low transference numbers (usually <0.55), and ion transport relies dominantly on ILs and/or polymers in pores rather than the MOFs. Later, ion conductive MOFs that can transport ions by the frameworks were developed. With anions coordinated to the open metal sites, MOFs, such as Mg2(dobdc) and MIT-20, can realize ion transport with metal salts and propylene carbonate (PC) molecules inside the pores. Few of them have been further applied as SEs in SSBs, for example, MOF-688 and CuBTC, with high lithium ion transference numbers of 0.87 and 0.65, respectively.

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have been intensively investigated as potential SEs due to their diversified structures and chemical tunability. Few of them have been further applied as SEs in SSBs, for example, MOF-688 and CuBTC, with high lithium ion transference numbers of 0.87 and 0.65, respectively.

elements.content: To apply MOFs in SSBs, MOF powders are usually mechanically mixed with a polymer to obtain a flexible SE membrane. However, the ion transport in such fabricated SE suffers from the poor interfacial compatibility, which is caused by the loose contact between MOF particles, the physical contact between the MOF and polymer binder, and the interface between the MOF and electrodes. In other words, the migration of ions across these contact areas is challenging, which will consequently impede the battery performance especially at high C rates and shorten the lifetime of SSBs. Despite the fact that the interface issues have been intensively studied in inorganic SEs, surprisingly, it has not yet been fully studied in MOF-based SEs.
elements.clean_text: To apply MOFs in SSBs, MOF powders are usually mechanically mixed with a polymer to obtain a flexible SE membrane. However, the ion transport in such fabricated SE suffers from the poor interfacial compatibility, which is caused by the loose contact between MOF particles, the physical contact between the MOF and polymer binder, and the interface between the MOF and electrodes. In other words, the migration of ions across these contact areas is challenging, which will consequently impede the battery performance especially at high C rates and shorten the lifetime of SSBs. Despite the fact that the interface issues have been intensively studied in inorganic SEs, surprisingly, it has not yet been fully studied in MOF-based SEs.

elements.content: To target MOF-based SEs with improved interfacial compatibility, it is necessary to form closer contacts and build ion transport channels between MOF particles. Inspired by the protein molecules on cell walls that help transport ions such as Na+, K+, and Ca2+, herein we propose to build ion transport pathways between MOF particles with an ionic conductive polymer via covalent bonding. As shown in , the surfaces of MOF particles were first embellished with cross-linking nodes (MOF-CN) and then polymerized MOFs (PMOF) were obtained via the in situ ring-opening reaction. The in situ ring-opening reaction not only connected MOF particles chemically to each other but also rendered a membrane that can be directly used as SE (SE-PMOF). The obtained SE-PMOF possesses good ion conductivity and a high Li+ transport number. Furthermore, it greatly decreases the interfacial resistance and improves the performance of assembled SSBs compared to the SEs composed of MOFs mechanically mixed with polymer binders.

elements.clean_text: 1  Illustration of Bioinspired Design and the Composition of SE-PMOF

elements.content: In this work, the physicochemically stable Zr-based MOF, UiO-66-2OH, was chosen for the fabrication of bioinspired SE, as the electronegative -OH groups are expected to bind Li+ and serve as hopping sites. Moreover, further chemical design is feasible with -OH groups. 3-Glycidoxypropyltrimethoxysilane (γ-GPS) was used to provide cross-linking nodes on MOF surfaces because of its suitable size and chemical property. The γ-GPS molecule is ∼11.7 Å in length and ∼5.6 Å in width (Figure S1) and slightly larger than the window size of UiO-66-2OH (<6 Å). Thus, the hydrolysis–condensation of γ-GPS is supposed to occur on the surface of MOF particles, ensuring that the inner aperture of MOF-CN remains unoccupied. XRD and SEM results demonstrate that MOF-CN preserves the crystal structure of UiO-66-2OH (Figure S2), and its particle size is ∼500 nm, without an obvious change from UiO-66-2OH (Figure S3). Compared with UiO-66-2OH, MOF-CN possesses a smaller BET surface area (785 m2 g–1 vs 520 m2 g–1) (Figure S4), suggesting the presence of γ-GPS. To further certify the existence of γ-GPS in MOF-CN, TGA and FT-IR were conducted. TGA data indicate that the organic content of MOF-CN is 2.2 wt % higher than that of UiO-66-2OH, which can be ascribed to grafted γ-GPS (Figure S5). The additional adsorption peak at 1095 cm–1 observed in FT-IR spectra of MOF-CN is assigned to the stretching vibration of the Si-O-C group, confirming that γ-GPS has been successfully grafted onto UiO-66-2OH (Figure S6a).

elements.content: The free-standing membrane (SE-PMOF) was then fabricated with MOF-CN, poly­(ethylene glycol) diglycidyl ether (PEGDE), and diaminopoly­(propylene glycol) (DPPG) through an in situ ring-opening reaction between a terminal epoxy group and -NH2 group (Figures S7 and S8). As one can see in FT-IR spectra, the peak at 993 cm–1 representing the epoxy group disappeared in SE-PMOF, while a new adsorption peak at 1012 cm–1 (assigned to the C-N group) appeared, indicating that the epoxy group of γ-GPS reacted with the amino group of DPPG to form SE-PMOF (Figure S6b). The crystallinity of MOF-CN particles remains intact during the ring-opening reaction as the XRD pattern of SE-PMOF resembles that of MOF-CN (Figure S2).
elements.clean_text: The free-standing membrane (SE-PMOF) was then fabricated with MOF-CN, poly(ethylene glycol) diglycidyl ether (PEGDE), and diaminopoly(propylene glycol) (DPPG) through an in situ ring-opening reaction between a terminal epoxy group and -NH2 group (Figures S7 and S8). As one can see in FT-IR spectra, the peak at 993 cm-1 representing the epoxy group disappeared in SE-PMOF, while a new adsorption peak at 1012 cm-1 (assigned to the C-N group) appeared, indicating that the epoxy group of γ-GPS reacted with the amino group of DPPG to form SE-PMOF (Figure S6b). The crystallinity of MOF-CN particles remains intact during the ring-opening reaction as the XRD pattern of SE-PMOF resembles that of MOF-CN (Figure S2).

elements.content: The calculated density of the SE-PMOF membrane is 0.32 g cm–3, while the densities of UiO-66-2OH pellets pressed under 1 and 2 MPa are 0.24 and 0.35 g cm–3, respectively (Figure S9). Thus, the density of SE-PMOF is close to that of the MOF pellet pressed under a pressure of 2 MPa, demonstrating that the in situ ring-opening reaction increased the stacking density of MOF particles and implying a close interface contact between MOF particles. One can seen in a that the MOF-CN particles are densely packed, and a very thin polymer overlayer can be observed between crystals. The side view of the SE-PMOF (b) shows that the membrane has a good uniform thickness, ∼60 μm. The morphologies of SE-PMOF and the typical SE fabricated with the MOF and polymer binder (UiO-66-2OH/PVDF-HFP) are compared in Figure S10. Under a higher magnification, the MOF particles in SE-PMOF are fully covered by the thin polymer overlayer and are closely connected to each other (Figure S10a). While voids between MOF particles can be clearly observed in the case of UiO-66-2OH/PVDF-HFP, the diameters of some voids are >100 nm (Figure S10b). Therefore, compared with the physical contact in UiO-66-2OH/PVDF-HFP, the covalent bonds formed between MOF particles and the polymer in SE-PMOF can significantly improve the interfacial compatibility.

elements.content: Both the mechanical property and the electronic conductivity were investigated to study the usability of the SE-PMOF. The SE-PMOF exhibits good flexibility and toughness (c). Tensile tests show that the dry SE-PMOF has a higher tensile strength, but its ductility is poor. The PC-wetted SE-PMOF possesses better ductility but a lower tensile strength (Figure S11). The tensile strength of the SE-PMOF is however lower than those of traditional polymers such as PEO and PVDF-HFP, which could be expected as the SE-PMOF is mainly composed of MOF particles and lacks long chain polymers. The electronic conductivity of the SE-PMOF was estimated with a multimeter, and the calculated electronic conductivity is 9.1 × 10–12 S cm–1, indicating that the SE-PMOF is an insulator.

elements.content: To study the electrochemical stability of the SE-PMOF, a linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) test was conducted at a scan rate of 1 mV s–1 with asymmetric Li|SE-PMOF|SS (SS is short for stainless steel) cells. The SE-PMOF demonstrates a wide electrochemical window as large as ∼4.6 V versus Li+/Li (d). To certify the superiority of SE-PMOF, the DPPG/PEGDE/PVDF-HFP and PVDF-HFP membrane were fabricated and tested under identical conditions. Both of them became unstable at ∼4 V versus Li+/Li (d), suggesting that the SE-PMOF has better electrochemical stability compared with that of the traditional polymeric SE.

The SE-PMOF demonstrates a wide electrochemical window as large as ~4.6 V versus Li+/Li (d). To certify the superiority of SE-PMOF, the DPPG/PEGDE/PVDF-HFP and PVDF-HFP membrane were fabricated and tested under identical conditions. Both of them became unstable at ~4 V versus Li+/Li (d), suggesting that the SE-PMOF has better electrochemical stability compared with that of the traditional polymeric SE.

elements.content: The ion transport ability of SE-PMOF was investigated by electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) at a range of temperatures from −20 to 60 °C (Figure S12). Migrations of Li+ and Zn2+ in the SE-PMOF were investigated as examples with LiTFSI, Zn­(TFSI)2, and Zn­(ClO4)2 as ion sources. The ionic conductivity of the SE-PMOF membrane increases with temperature and is calculated to be 1.70 × 10–3, 1.43 × 10–3, and 2.87 × 10–3 S cm–1 (at 30 °C) for LiTFSI, Zn­(TFSI)2, and Zn­(ClO4)2, respectively (e and Table S1). Moreover, the conductivity shows Arrhenius-type activated behavior, and the calculated ion migration energies are 0.27, 0.37, and 0.31 eV, respectively (f). The difference in ion conductivity between the use of Zn­(TFSI)2 and Zn­(ClO4)2 reveals that the anion can affect the transport of metal ions, as well, implying that more electronegative chemical groups promote ion transport better. For comparison, UiO-66-2OH pellets and SE membranes composed of UiO-66-2OH and PVDF-HFP (UiO-66-2OH/PVDF-HFP) were prepared. They were tested with the same procedures as the SE-PMOF. UiO-66-2OH and UiO-66-2OH/PVDF-HFP show Li+ conductivities of 4.35 × 10–5 and 3.32 × 10–4 S cm–1 at 30 °C, respectively (Figure S13), which are smaller than that of SE-PMOF (1.70 × 10–3 S cm–1). TGA curves manifest that the estimated PC contents in the SE-PMOF, UiO-66-2OH pellet, and UiO-66-2OH/PVDF-HFP are 27.3, 34.3, and 27.8 wt %, respectively (Figure S14), which excludes the contribution of PC to the enhanced ion conductivity of the SE-PMOF. The Li+ conductivity of SE-PMOF is even higher than those of other previously reported MOFs applied in SSBs (Table S2 and Figure S15), which we attribute to the optimized interfacial compatibility in polymerized MOFs.

elements.content: Because both positive and negative ions migrate during ion conductivity tests, the real conductivity of positive ions needs to be confirmed by ion transport number. Herein, the Li+ transference number (t Li+ ) in the SE-PMOF was evaluated with the potentiostatic polarization method using a Li|SE-PMOF|Li symmetric cell. The current–time plots and EIS before and after 10 mV potential polarization are summarized in Figure S16. The t Li+ of SE-PMOF is calculated to be ≤0.8, much higher than that of the liquid electrolyte, which is usually in the range of 0.2–0.4. The single ion transport ability of SE-PMOF in this work is the best among the reported SEs with MOFs (Table S2).

elements.content: The interaction between Li+ and the framework was further studied via X-ray phosphorescence (XPS) to elucidate the mechanism of ion transport (Figure S17). The Li 1s peak in the spectra of LiTFSI belongs to Li–N (at 56.0 eV), and after LiTFSI was adsorbed into UiO-66-2OH, the Li 1s peak shifts to 56.2 eV, which can be ascribed to a Li–O bond due to Lewis acid–base interaction. This result indicates that the oxygen atoms in -OH groups are favorable sites during ion hopping. For TFSI–, it has been reported that F, O, and N atoms can interact with hydrogen atoms in the framework; however, the movement of TFSI– will be hindered due to its much larger size and adsorption energy than Li+. Combining the information listed in Table S2, one can conclude that restricting the movement of TFSI– and promoting the hopping of Li+ with electronegative groups in the framework may lead to a high Li+ transference number.

This result indicates that the oxygen atoms in -OH groups are favorable sites during ion hopping. For TFSI-, it has been reported that F, O, and N atoms can interact with hydrogen atoms in the framework; however, the movement of TFSI- will be hindered due to its much larger size and adsorption energy than Li+. Combining the information listed in Table S2, one can conclude that restricting the movement of TFSI- and promoting the hopping of Li+ with electronegative groups in the framework may lead to a high Li+ transference number.

elements.content: Previous Li+ conductivity has proven the superiority of SE-PMOF over UiO-66-2OH/PVDF-HFP; here the interface resistances of the UiO-66-2OH/PVDF-HFP membrane, the UiO-66-2OH/DPPG/PEGDE pellet, the UiO-66-2OH pellet, and the SE-PMOF with electrodes (lithium metal) were further compared to elaborate the impact of different preparation routes (Figure S18). UiO-66-2OH/PVDF-HFP shows an interface resistance of 337.4 Ω. Both the UiO-66-2OH/DPPG/PEGDE pellet (Figure S19) and the UiO-66-2OH pellet show much higher interface resistances (Figure S18b). By contrast, the SE-PMOF has the lowest interface resistance of 34.0 Ω (Figure S18a). The lower interface resistance of the SE-PMOF can be ascribed to the optimized interface contact between the SE and lithium metal: compared with the point contact between the MOF/PVDF-HFP and lithium metal, additional Li+ transport pathways from SE to lithium metal are supplied by the covalently bonded organics between MOFs in the SE-PMOF, which improves the interfacial compatibility.

elements.content: Characterizations for Li plating/stripping stability were also conducted to evaluate the ability of SE-PMOF to suppress Li dendrite formation. Both the PVDF-HFP membrane and the SE-PMOF were implemented in a Li|Li symmetric cell of the 2032 type under a current density of 0.25 mA cm–2, and a current areal capacity of 0.25 mA h cm–2 was applied. One can see in a that the Li|SE-PMOF|Li symmetric cell has an initial overpotential of merely 46 mV, and the final overpotential slightly increases to 100 mV after 600 h. The voltage profiles remain flat, and no sign of short circuit is observed after 600 h, suggesting a stable Li plating/stripping process and suppressed Li dendrite growth. By contrast, the overpotential of the Li|PVDF-HFP|Li symmetric cell increases rapidly from 52 to 233 mV after 230 h, indicating a quickly increasing internal resistance caused by the growth of lithium dendrites, and then the lithium dendrites penetrate the PVDF-HFP membrane, leading to short circuit; thus, a sudden decrease in overpotential is observed at 230 h. The critical current density (CCD) of cells with the SE-PMOF, DPPG/PEGDE/PVDF-HFP, and PVDF-HFP as the SE was investigated (Figure S20). The CCDs of the Li|PVDF-HFP|Li cell and Li/DPPG/PEGDE/PVDF-HFP/Li cell are only 0.2 and 0.8 mA cm–2, respectively, while the CCD of the Li/SE-PMOF/Li cell has been substantially improved to 1.2 mA cm–2. The significant improvement of the CCD of the SE-PMOF is believed to be contributed by the stable electrochemical window and the optimized interfacial compatibility.
elements.clean_text: Characterizations for Li plating/stripping stability were also conducted to evaluate the ability of SE-PMOF to suppress Li dendrite formation. Both the PVDF-HFP membrane and the SE-PMOF were implemented in a Li|Li symmetric cell of the 2032 type under a current density of 0.25 mA cm-2, and a current areal capacity of 0.25 mA h cm-2 was applied. One can see in a that the Li|SE-PMOF|Li symmetric cell has an initial overpotential of merely 46 mV, and the final overpotential slightly increases to 100 mV after 600 h. The voltage profiles remain flat, and no sign of short circuit is observed after 600 h, suggesting a stable Li plating/stripping process and suppressed Li dendrite growth. By contrast, the overpotential of the Li|PVDF-HFP|Li symmetric cell increases rapidly from 52 to 233 mV after 230 h, indicating a quickly increasing internal resistance caused by the growth of lithium dendrites, and then the lithium dendrites penetrate the PVDF-HFP membrane, leading to short circuit; thus, a sudden decrease in overpotential is observed at 230 h. The critical current density (CCD) of cells with the SE-PMOF, DPPG/PEGDE/PVDF-HFP, and PVDF-HFP as the SE was investigated (Figure S20). The CCDs of the Li|PVDF-HFP|Li cell and Li/DPPG/PEGDE/PVDF-HFP/Li cell are only 0.2 and 0.8 mA cm-2, respectively, while the CCD of the Li/SE-PMOF/Li cell has been substantially improved to 1.2 mA cm-2. The significant improvement of the CCD of the SE-PMOF is believed to be contributed by the stable electrochemical window and the optimized interfacial compatibility.

elements.content: In addition, Zn plating/stripping tests were conducted with fiberglass diaphragm and SE-PMOF separately implemented in a Zn|Zn symmetric cell of the 2032 type under a current density of 0.25 mA cm–2. As illustrated in b, the initial voltage hysteresis of the Zn|SE-PMOF|Zn symmetric cell is 86 mV and moderately increases to 111 mV after 800 h, whereas the symmetric cell with a fiberglass diaphragm in an electrolyte shows an initial overpotential of 62 mV; however, short circuit and a sudden decrease in overpotential appear after 616 h, implying that the Zn dendrites punctured the fiberglass diaphragm. The formation of Zn dendrites with the cycled Zn metal electrodes was directly observed by SEM. For the Zn|Zn symmetric cell using the SE-PMOF, no obvious bulky Zn dendrites can be observed on top of the Zn metal (Figure S21a). By comparison, the liquid Zn|Zn symmetric cell using a fiberglass diaphragm as a separator showcases bulky and conglobate Zn dendrites over 10 μm (Figure S21b), which eventually leads to the failure of the symmetric cell. Therefore, the results confirm that the SE-PMOF can effectively suppress the formation of Zn dendrites.

elements.content: To further investigate the applicability of the SE-PMOF as the SE in the SSB, SE-PMOF and MOF/PVDF-HFP were implemented in Li metal cells with LiFePO4 as the counter electrode. As shown in panels a and b of , the LiFePO4 cell with the SE-PMOF has specific capacities of 153, 150, 144, and 130 mAh g–1 at 0.2, 0.5, 1, and 2 C, respectively. By contrast, the cell with MOF/PVDF-HFP as the SE shows C rate performances of only 137, 132, and 125 mAh g–1 at 0.2, 0.5, and 1 C, respectively. Specifically, its specific capacity at 2 C declines rapidly from 102 to 68 mAh g–1 in five cycles, which can be caused by the insufficient Li+ transport at a high C rate. The cycling performance of the cell with the SE-PMOF was further investigated. In panels c and d of , the cell shows a stable cycling performance at 0.2 C, and the specific capacity remains at 145 mAh g–1 after 100 cycles, rendering a high retention of 97.7%. The decay rate per cycle is as low as 0.29‰. The cycling performance at 1 C was further studied to show its practicability at a high C rate. It can be seen in panels e and f of that after 500 cycles, the specific capacity slowly decreases to 127 mAh g–1 from the initial 138 mAh g–1, showing a decay rate of 0.15‰. The cell also exhibits good cycling performance at a higher current at 2 C. The specific capacity is as high as 114 mAh g–1 after 350 cycles, and the decay rate per cycle is as low as 0.14‰ (Figure S22). The comparison of SSB performance with other reported MOF-based SEs can be found in Table S3 and Figure S23. One can conclude that the SSB performance in this work is outstanding. With respect to , we assume that the optimized interfacial compatibility in the SE-PMOF and the suppressed Li dendrite growth contribute greatly to the improved specific capacity and cycling performance of the quasi-solid Li metal cell implemented with the SE-PMOF.

elements.content: To certify the versatility of the SE-PMOF in the battery, the SE-PMOF was implemented in Zn metal cells with NH4V4O10 as the counter electrode. Panels a and b of show that the specific capacities of the fabricated Zn metal cell at current densities of 0.1, 0.2, and 0.5 A g–1 are 435, 419, and 335 mAh g–1, respectively. At a higher current density of 1 A g–1, the specific capacity decreases to 242 mAh g–1. The cycling performance at 0.1 A g–1 is shown in panels c and d of , with a scarcely decayed charge/discharge process in 50 cycles. Panels e and f of display the cycling stability of the solid cell at a higher current of 0.5 A g–1. The specific capacity declined from 331 to 310 mAh g–1 after 250 cycles, with a decay rate of ∼0.26‰ per cycle. This performance is better than that of the previously reported Zn cell with PVDF-HFP as the ion conductor. The excellent capacity and cyclic performance of the Zn metal battery with the SE-PMOF thus suggest that the newly designed SE holds great potential for extensive use in solid batteries.

elements.content: In summary, we have proposed and proved experimentally a simple but very efficient strategy for optimizing interfacial compatibility to promote ion transport in the MOF-based SE. The high t Li+ (0.8) suggests that the designed SE-PMOF can realize single ion transport. Compared with the conventionally fabricated SE by mechanical mixing, the SE-PMOF can upgrade the physical contact to covalent bonding between MOF particles. The advantage of the SE-PMOF has been verified by both plating/stripping tests and the battery performance at various current densities. Higher ion conductivity, lower interface resistance, and better battery performance are realized on the basis of the SE-PMOF. This finding thus exploits a new avenue for overcoming the barrier of ion transport across physical interfaces between MOF particles, which is expected to be widely applicable for the development of the high-performance SE based on other porous materials in various solid batteries.

cln_elements.content:
Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have been attracting a great deal of attention as potential solid electrolytes (SEs). However, the interfacial compatibility of MOF-based SEs caused by the physical contact among MOF particles, the polymer binder, and electrodes is not yet fully determined. Herein, a bioinspired design strategy aiming to build ion transport pathways at interfaces was introduced. The MOF-to-MOF transport paths were built via in situ ring opening of epoxide, akin to the protein molecules that transport the ion across the cell walls. After optimization, the obtained SE is endowed with a high ion conductivity of 1.70 × 10–3 S cm–1 at 30 °C, a wide electrochemical window of 4.6 V, a high Li+ transference number of 0.8, and a decreased interface resistance. Consequently, the fabricated quasi-solid metal batteries exhibit higher and more stable cycling performance compared to the performance of those without interface optimization. This strategy for optimizing the interfacial compatibility of MOFs thus exploits a new avenue for developing high-performance SEs for various metal batteries.

In this work, the physicochemically stable Zr-based MOF, UiO-66-2OH, was chosen for the fabrication of bioinspired SE, as the electronegative -OH groups are expected to bind Li+ and serve as hopping sites. Moreover, further chemical design is feasible with -OH groups. 3-Glycidoxypropyltrimethoxysilane (γ-GPS) was used to provide cross-linking nodes on MOF surfaces because of its suitable size and chemical property. The γ-GPS molecule is ∼11.7 Å in length and ∼5.6 Å in width (Figure S1) and slightly larger than the window size of UiO-66-2OH (<6 Å). Thus, the hydrolysis–condensation of γ-GPS is supposed to occur on the surface of MOF particles, ensuring that the inner aperture of MOF-CN remains unoccupied. XRD and SEM results demonstrate that MOF-CN preserves the crystal structure of UiO-66-2OH (Figure S2), and its particle size is ∼500 nm, without an obvious change from UiO-66-2OH (Figure S3). Compared with UiO-66-2OH, MOF-CN possesses a smaller BET surface area (785 m2 g–1 vs 520 m2 g–1) (Figure S4), suggesting the presence of γ-GPS. To further certify the existence of γ-GPS in MOF-CN, TGA and FT-IR were conducted. TGA data indicate that the organic content of MOF-CN is 2.2 wt % higher than that of UiO-66-2OH, which can be ascribed to grafted γ-GPS (Figure S5). The additional adsorption peak at 1095 cm–1 observed in FT-IR spectra of MOF-CN is assigned to the stretching vibration of the Si-O-C group, confirming that γ-GPS has been successfully grafted onto UiO-66-2OH (Figure S6a).

The calculated density of the SE-PMOF membrane is 0.32 g cm–3, while the densities of UiO-66-2OH pellets pressed under 1 and 2 MPa are 0.24 and 0.35 g cm–3, respectively (Figure S9). Thus, the density of SE-PMOF is close to that of the MOF pellet pressed under a pressure of 2 MPa, demonstrating that the in situ ring-opening reaction increased the stacking density of MOF particles and implying a close interface contact between MOF particles. One can seen in a that the MOF-CN particles are densely packed, and a very thin polymer overlayer can be observed between crystals. The side view of the SE-PMOF (b) shows that the membrane has a good uniform thickness, ∼60 μm. The morphologies of SE-PMOF and the typical SE fabricated with the MOF and polymer binder (UiO-66-2OH/PVDF-HFP) are compared in Figure S10. Under a higher magnification, the MOF particles in SE-PMOF are fully covered by the thin polymer overlayer and are closely connected to each other (Figure S10a). While voids between MOF particles can be clearly observed in the case of UiO-66-2OH/PVDF-HFP, the diameters of some voids are >100 nm (Figure S10b). Therefore, compared with the physical contact in UiO-66-2OH/PVDF-HFP, the covalent bonds formed between MOF particles and the polymer in SE-PMOF can significantly improve the interfacial compatibility.

Both the mechanical property and the electronic conductivity were investigated to study the usability of the SE-PMOF. The SE-PMOF exhibits good flexibility and toughness (c). Tensile tests show that the dry SE-PMOF has a higher tensile strength, but its ductility is poor. The PC-wetted SE-PMOF possesses better ductility but a lower tensile strength (Figure S11). The tensile strength of the SE-PMOF is however lower than those of traditional polymers such as PEO and PVDF-HFP, which could be expected as the SE-PMOF is mainly composed of MOF particles and lacks long chain polymers. The electronic conductivity of the SE-PMOF was estimated with a multimeter, and the calculated electronic conductivity is 9.1 × 10–12 S cm–1, indicating that the SE-PMOF is an insulator.

To study the electrochemical stability of the SE-PMOF, a linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) test was conducted at a scan rate of 1 mV s–1 with asymmetric Li|SE-PMOF|SS (SS is short for stainless steel) cells. The SE-PMOF demonstrates a wide electrochemical window as large as ∼4.6 V versus Li+/Li (d). To certify the superiority of SE-PMOF, the DPPG/PEGDE/PVDF-HFP and PVDF-HFP membrane were fabricated and tested under identical conditions. Both of them became unstable at ∼4 V versus Li+/Li (d), suggesting that the SE-PMOF has better electrochemical stability compared with that of the traditional polymeric SE.

The ion transport ability of SE-PMOF was investigated by electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) at a range of temperatures from −20 to 60 °C (Figure S12). Migrations of Li+ and Zn2+ in the SE-PMOF were investigated as examples with LiTFSI, Zn­(TFSI)2, and Zn­(ClO4)2 as ion sources. The ionic conductivity of the SE-PMOF membrane increases with temperature and is calculated to be 1.70 × 10–3, 1.43 × 10–3, and 2.87 × 10–3 S cm–1 (at 30 °C) for LiTFSI, Zn­(TFSI)2, and Zn­(ClO4)2, respectively (e and Table S1). Moreover, the conductivity shows Arrhenius-type activated behavior, and the calculated ion migration energies are 0.27, 0.37, and 0.31 eV, respectively (f). The difference in ion conductivity between the use of Zn­(TFSI)2 and Zn­(ClO4)2 reveals that the anion can affect the transport of metal ions, as well, implying that more electronegative chemical groups promote ion transport better. For comparison, UiO-66-2OH pellets and SE membranes composed of UiO-66-2OH and PVDF-HFP (UiO-66-2OH/PVDF-HFP) were prepared. They were tested with the same procedures as the SE-PMOF. UiO-66-2OH and UiO-66-2OH/PVDF-HFP show Li+ conductivities of 4.35 × 10–5 and 3.32 × 10–4 S cm–1 at 30 °C, respectively (Figure S13), which are smaller than that of SE-PMOF (1.70 × 10–3 S cm–1). TGA curves manifest that the estimated PC contents in the SE-PMOF, UiO-66-2OH pellet, and UiO-66-2OH/PVDF-HFP are 27.3, 34.3, and 27.8 wt %, respectively (Figure S14), which excludes the contribution of PC to the enhanced ion conductivity of the SE-PMOF. The Li+ conductivity of SE-PMOF is even higher than those of other previously reported MOFs applied in SSBs (Table S2 and Figure S15), which we attribute to the optimized interfacial compatibility in polymerized MOFs.

Because both positive and negative ions migrate during ion conductivity tests, the real conductivity of positive ions needs to be confirmed by ion transport number. Herein, the Li+ transference number (t Li+ ) in the SE-PMOF was evaluated with the potentiostatic polarization method using a Li|SE-PMOF|Li symmetric cell. The current–time plots and EIS before and after 10 mV potential polarization are summarized in Figure S16. The t Li+ of SE-PMOF is calculated to be ≤0.8, much higher than that of the liquid electrolyte, which is usually in the range of 0.2–0.4. The single ion transport ability of SE-PMOF in this work is the best among the reported SEs with MOFs (Table S2).

The Li+ conductivity of SE-PMOF is even higher than those of other previously reported MOFs applied in SSBs (Table S2 and Figure S15), which we attribute to the optimized interfacial compatibility in polymerized MOFs. 

Because both positive and negative ions migrate during ion conductivity tests, the real conductivity of positive ions needs to be confirmed by ion transport number. Herein, the Li+ transference number (t Li+ ) in the SE-PMOF was evaluated with the potentiostatic polarization method using a Li|SE-PMOF|Li symmetric cell. The current-time plots and EIS before and after 10 mV potential polarization are summarized in Figure S16. The t Li+  of SE-PMOF is calculated to be ≤0.8, much higher than that of the liquid electrolyte, which is usually in the range of 0.2-0.4. The single ion transport ability of SE-PMOF in this work is the best among the reported SEs with MOFs (Table S2).

cln_elements.content:
Previous Li+ conductivity has proven the superiority of SE-PMOF over UiO-66-2OH/PVDF-HFP; here the interface resistances of the UiO-66-2OH/PVDF-HFP membrane, the UiO-66-2OH/DPPG/PEGDE pellet, the UiO-66-2OH pellet, and the SE-PMOF with electrodes (lithium metal) were further compared to elaborate the impact of different preparation routes (Figure S18). UiO-66-2OH/PVDF-HFP shows an interface resistance of 337.4 Ω. Both the UiO-66-2OH/DPPG/PEGDE pellet (Figure S19) and the UiO-66-2OH pellet show much higher interface resistances (Figure S18b). By contrast, the SE-PMOF has the lowest interface resistance of 34.0 Ω (Figure S18a). The lower interface resistance of the SE-PMOF can be ascribed to the optimized interface contact between the SE and lithium metal: compared with the point contact between the MOF/PVDF-HFP and lithium metal, additional Li+ transport pathways from SE to lithium metal are supplied by the covalently bonded organics between MOFs in the SE-PMOF, which improves the interfacial compatibility.

Characterizations for Li plating/stripping stability were also conducted to evaluate the ability of SE-PMOF to suppress Li dendrite formation. Both the PVDF-HFP membrane and the SE-PMOF were implemented in a Li|Li symmetric cell of the 2032 type under a current density of 0.25 mA cm–2, and a current areal capacity of 0.25 mA h cm–2 was applied. One can see in a that the Li|SE-PMOF|Li symmetric cell has an initial overpotential of merely 46 mV, and the final overpotential slightly increases to 100 mV after 600 h. The voltage profiles remain flat, and no sign of short circuit is observed after 600 h, suggesting a stable Li plating/stripping process and suppressed Li dendrite growth. By contrast, the overpotential of the Li|PVDF-HFP|Li symmetric cell increases rapidly from 52 to 233 mV after 230 h, indicating a quickly increasing internal resistance caused by the growth of lithium dendrites, and then the lithium dendrites penetrate the PVDF-HFP membrane, leading to short circuit; thus, a sudden decrease in overpotential is observed at 230 h. The critical current density (CCD) of cells with the SE-PMOF, DPPG/PEGDE/PVDF-HFP, and PVDF-HFP as the SE was investigated (Figure S20). The CCDs of the Li|PVDF-HFP|Li cell and Li/DPPG/PEGDE/PVDF-HFP/Li cell are only 0.2 and 0.8 mA cm–2, respectively, while the CCD of the Li/SE-PMOF/Li cell has been substantially improved to 1.2 mA cm–2. The significant improvement of the CCD of the SE-PMOF is believed to be contributed by the stable electrochemical window and the optimized interfacial compatibility.

In addition, Zn plating/stripping tests were conducted with fiberglass diaphragm and SE-PMOF separately implemented in a Zn|Zn symmetric cell of the 2032 type under a current density of 0.25 mA cm–2. As illustrated in b, the initial voltage hysteresis of the Zn|SE-PMOF|Zn symmetric cell is 86 mV and moderately increases to 111 mV after 800 h, whereas the symmetric cell with a fiberglass diaphragm in an electrolyte shows an initial overpotential of 62 mV; however, short circuit and a sudden decrease in overpotential appear after 616 h, implying that the Zn dendrites punctured the fiberglass diaphragm. The formation of Zn dendrites with the cycled Zn metal electrodes was directly observed by SEM. For the Zn|Zn symmetric cell using the SE-PMOF, no obvious bulky Zn dendrites can be observed on top of the Zn metal (Figure S21a). By comparison, the liquid Zn|Zn symmetric cell using a fiberglass diaphragm as a separator showcases bulky and conglobate Zn dendrites over 10 μm (Figure S21b), which eventually leads to the failure of the symmetric cell. Therefore, the results confirm that the SE-PMOF can effectively suppress the formation of Zn dendrites.

To further investigate the applicability of the SE-PMOF as the SE in the SSB, SE-PMOF and MOF/PVDF-HFP were implemented in Li metal cells with LiFePO4 as the counter electrode. As shown in panels a and b of , the LiFePO4 cell with the SE-PMOF has specific capacities of 153, 150, 144, and 130 mAh g–1 at 0.2, 0.5, 1, and 2 C, respectively. By contrast, the cell with MOF/PVDF-HFP as the SE shows C rate performances of only 137, 132, and 125 mAh g–1 at 0.2, 0.5, and 1 C, respectively. Specifically, its specific capacity at 2 C declines rapidly from 102 to 68 mAh g–1 in five cycles, which can be caused by the insufficient Li+ transport at a high C rate. The cycling performance of the cell with the SE-PMOF was further investigated. In panels c and d of , the cell shows a stable cycling performance at 0.2 C, and the specific capacity remains at 145 mAh g–1 after 100 cycles, rendering a high retention of 97.7%. The decay rate per cycle is as low as 0.29‰. The cycling performance at 1 C was further studied to show its practicability at a high C rate. It can be seen in panels e and f of that after 500 cycles, the specific capacity slowly decreases to 127 mAh g–1 from the initial 138 mAh g–1, showing a decay rate of 0.15‰. The cell also exhibits good cycling performance at a higher current at 2 C. The specific capacity is as high as 114 mAh g–1 after 350 cycles, and the decay rate per cycle is as low as 0.14‰ (Figure S22). The comparison of SSB performance with other reported MOF-based SEs can be found in Table S3 and Figure S23. One can conclude that the SSB performance in this work is outstanding. With respect to , we assume that the optimized interfacial compatibility in the SE-PMOF and the suppressed Li dendrite growth contribute greatly to the improved specific capacity and cycling performance of the quasi-solid Li metal cell implemented with the SE-PMOF.

To certify the versatility of the SE-PMOF in the battery, the SE-PMOF was implemented in Zn metal cells with NH4V4O10 as the counter electrode. Panels a and b of show that the specific capacities of the fabricated Zn metal cell at current densities of 0.1, 0.2, and 0.5 A g–1 are 435, 419, and 335 mAh g–1, respectively. At a higher current density of 1 A g–1, the specific capacity decreases to 242 mAh g–1. The cycling performance at 0.1 A g–1 is shown in panels c and d of , with a scarcely decayed charge/discharge process in 50 cycles. Panels e and f of display the cycling stability of the solid cell at a higher current of 0.5 A g–1. The specific capacity declined from 331 to 310 mAh g–1 after 250 cycles, with a decay rate of ∼0.26‰ per cycle. This performance is better than that of the previously reported Zn cell with PVDF-HFP as the ion conductor. The excellent capacity and cyclic performance of the Zn metal battery with the SE-PMOF thus suggest that the newly designed SE holds great potential for extensive use in solid batteries.

In summary, we have proposed and proved experimentally a simple but very efficient strategy for optimizing interfacial compatibility to promote ion transport in the MOF-based SE. The high t Li+ (0.8) suggests that the designed SE-PMOF can realize single ion transport. Compared with the conventionally fabricated SE by mechanical mixing, the SE-PMOF can upgrade the physical contact to covalent bonding between MOF particles. The advantage of the SE-PMOF has been verified by both plating/stripping tests and the battery performance at various current densities. Higher ion conductivity, lower interface resistance, and better battery performance are realized on the basis of the SE-PMOF. This finding thus exploits a new avenue for overcoming the barrier of ion transport across physical interfaces between MOF particles, which is expected to be widely applicable for the development of the high-performance SE based on other porous materials in various solid batteries.
